result.execSummary:
The defendant Paul M. Stewart was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Burglary-Building or Dwelling, a class F felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.10(1m)(a).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: If revoked, credit for 3 or 4 days of KCJ is requested.

miscConds.notes: If probation or extended supervision is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and governmental entities for the balance due.  Collections may include income assignment.  This applies to all counts and financial obligations.

Obey all of the rules and regulations of supervising probation agent.  
*  Pay supervision fees.  
*  Pay all court costs including all applicable surcharges.  
*  Submit to a DNA sample (Unless previously provided) and pay surcharge.  
*  Pay costs of legal representation or Advocate Counsel fees for the defense of the case - PD Atty Rufo if determined within 45 days.   
*  Pay resitution plus surcharges; the State shall have 60 days to determine restitution.  
DOC Shall promptly notify the Court of any new arrest or criminal charge made against the deft.
  If unpaid financial obligations remain at discharge or revocation, civil judgment to be entered.
